To make this analogy more firm we may calculate the axial field of a finite solenoid depicted in Fig. 5.3 (a). We can demonstrate that at large distances this axial field resembles that of a bar magnet.

The magnitude of the field at point  $\mathrm{P}$  due to the solenoid is

$$
B = \frac {\mu_ {0}}{4 \pi} \frac {2 m}{r ^ {3}} \tag {5.1}
$$
header_path: 5.2.2 Bar magnet as an equivalent solenoid
summary: Discussing the use of an axial field of a finite solenoid as an analogy for a bar magnet, emphasizing its resemblance at large distances.
hypothetical_questions: How does the axial field of an infinite solenoid compare to that of a finite solenoid?
Under what conditions can the axial field of a finite solenoid be accurately likened to that of a bar magnet?
What is the significance of this analogy and how might it aid our understanding of magnetic fields?
